In two recent posts, thing:16508 and thing:16968, I provided polyhedron openSCAD commands based on the polyhedra libary at netlib. http://netlib.sandia.gov/polyhedra/ The Catalan bodies were the only convex polyhedra that remained undone in the library and I have now converted them to openSCAD polyhedron commands. There was one Catalan polyhedron missing from the library, the triakis tetrahedron. To make an openSCAD polyhedron command one needs a set of vertex coordinates and information about how to connect the vertices to make triangles. By typing "triakis tetrahedron coordinates" in Wolfram/Alpha - http://www.wolframalpha.com/ I obtained a set of vertex coordinates. A table of distances showed where the triangles should be placed. All of the Catalan stl files are included in hollow_catalan_stl.zip and the scad files that produced them are in hollow_catalan_scad.zip. A module containing the polyhedon command that produces the polyhedra is at the end of each scad file and can be extracted and used in other openSCAD programs. I have printed all of the stl files, some multiple times. Stl files of Catalan solids that print particularly well are included below. Two with 12 faces are the triakis tetrahedron and the rhombic dodecahedron. One with 24 faces that prints well is the trapezoidal icositetrahedron. An interesting one with 24 faces is the pentagonal icositetrahedron. It occurs as enantiomorphs; that is mirror images which do not superimpose. The picture at the left shows the two forms and the stl files used to print them are included below. The Catalan solids are named for a Belgium mathematician, EugÃ¨ne Catalan, who first wrote about them in the mid 19th century. They are derived from the Archimedian solids. Much information about them is available on the internet; "Catalan solids" entered in Google usually results in more than one million hits.

The minimum number of faces for the Catalan polyhedra is 12 and the maximum number 120.  Polyhedra with fewer than 60 faces print well but those with 60 or more faces are difficult.  I find that external support is necessary and that the faces closest to the build platform and most distant from the build platform are poorly done.
The files were printed on a Thing-O-Matic printer using a heated build surface covered with Kapton tape.  The tape was cleaned with acetone before each print and the models adhered well to the surface.  A raft was used.  External support was added for polyhedra with 60 or more faces.

remixed_from.title: Simple Rifle Attachment for "THE NEST" Vive Controller, designed

title: Simple Rifle Attachment for "THE NEST" Vive Controller, designed by Alien Identity Revision 3. by Alien_Identity

description.text:
Revision 3:

Parts 1Rev2 and 2Rev2 had dovetails that were to large, and those two parts have now been replaced with Part1Rev3 and Part3Rev3. I have double checked and can confirm that the Rev3 parts now have the 0.3mm clearance needed for an easy fit into Part2Rev2's dovetail cut-outs.

I have modified the design and included an ISO metric M30 x 3.5mm pitch internally threaded locator and an externally threaded cap to lock the Vive controller in place. The threads have been added in Fusion360 ( CAD program ) and I hope they have survived the conversion to STL file.

description.text: This is a 3D Filament Spool Mount design for the MPCNC (Mostly Printed CNC). It uses the same conduit size as the MPCNC so if you have left over scrap tubing you can use it to make this mount. One of the problems with the MPCNC was that there was no easy way to have your filament sitting and feeding the MPCNC so I designed this to solve that problem. Since it has a simple design you can consider it to be a single or double filament holder using 1 vertical and 1 horizontal bar, or you can use a long horizontal bar with 2 vertical bars, 4 pole mounts and 2 Joints. That would allow you to hold a lot of filament all attached to your table. Where ever your table moves to is now where your filament moves as well. Enjoy!

title: world of warcraft undead female warlock felheart channeled casting
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This printed "real good" (as my notes indicate), ~3.25in tall in 2h19m. Build settings:
  • raft + full support
  • 10% infill
  • 0.2mm layer height
  • 1 extra shell
  • 80mm/s feed, 150mm/s travel
  • heated build plate @115c
    • It printed with a TON of support material which took a couple hours to clean. wound up breaking one of the arms while cleaning (her elbows are mere bones !) but it super-glues back together really well. mannoroth !

I exported the model from the program "wow model viewer", where I dressed her in felheart and selected her pose. You will need a full installation of Blizzard's World of Warcraft in order to run the model viewer (I'm not sure if you can do this using the "free" version of WoW, but I don't see why not).

author: sandwich

description.text:
LCD 12864 holder on adjustable stand

IMPORTANT: Do not over tighten bolts.

I have modified the files based on a Front Cover and the Back Plate print, these new modified the files are untested but the Front Cover and the Back Plate that hold the LCD 12864 should now fit together better.

LCD 12864 Adjustable Stand First Full Test Fit. Seems to function well :-
https://youtu.be/JN-Lvyfj-Jw via @YouTube

There is a cut out for easier SD removal.

The "lcd_12864_ball_mount.stl" needed printing with the cups facing up and supports turned on. This is to prevent bad plastic inside the cups that need to contact the ball joint.

It may be best to print the Ball, (lcd_12864_ball_mount.stl), and Socket, (lcd_12864_ball_holder.stl) parts set to fine, 0.01mm layer height, to make them move smoothly together.

There are two knob types :-
lcd_12864_main_knob_round_shaft.stl ( For round shafts, not tested for fit)
lcd_12864_main_knob_flat_edged.stl (For shafts with a flat edge)
There are two other knob types similar but have less depth on the turning part, the filename begins with "less". These are here for completeness. Remember there are lots of different knob shaft types.

I have also made a the Back Cover and the Ball joint Mounting, (inside_mounting), so that they can be easier fastened together from the inside of the Back Cover. It was a bit difficult for me to bolt the Ball joint Mount onto the Back Cover because the Ball restricted easy access.

Using these; fasten the Ball joint Mounting to the Back Cover from the inside of the Back Cover first then fasten this to to the front cover.

Remember to add the Reset Button before putting the PCB into the Front cover.

These two files are :-
inside_bolt_mounting_lcd_12864_ball_mount.stl
and
inside_bolt_mounting_lcd_12864_back_cover.stl

There are now two Reset button's, I found that one, (lcd_12864_reset_button_loose.stl), could move too much if this unit is tipped. This was just annoying if this unit was tipped about making a loose sound, see video. So I made a Reset Button that should move about less, (lcd_12864_reset_button.stl).

NOTE: At 20% infill the PCB supports can break if the holes are not pre-drilled. I drill bolt holes out at 2.5mm then screw a bolt in to pre-cut the threads in PLA.

IMPORTANT: Do not over tighten bolts.

I have created a Back Plate with out any holes in, if you want to use without the stand, file:-

no_back_holes_lcd_12864_back_cover.stl

YouTube Playlist, this will show you the iterations:-
LCD 12864 holder on adjustable stand
https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLUqt0sTiXUDepbEIl2jWd0YF-dSa3o3a4

description.text:
This a simple universal iPhone charging dock. I wanted one that would work with all iPhones that use the lighting connector. It also works with many low profile cases.

I uploaded two versions. One fits iPhone without a case or a slim/low-profile case. The other dubbed Lifeproof is for bulkier cases. It has beed tested with the Lifproof case, and will likely work with other bulkier cases.

The dock was printed in ColorFabb WoodFill and CorkFill and the Dock Base was printed in NinjaTeck NinjaFlex.

The Dock Base is optional if you don't have a printer capable of printing flexible materials.

Yes the Amazon Basics lightening cable fits perfectly as does the standard Apple lightening cable.

I have also added the original Autodesk Fusion 360 files. Please excuse the mess modeling work, this was one of my first CAD modeling projects.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

100

Notes:

I used 100% infill, because I like the weight that dock has when it is completely solid. Printed in Hatchbox Wood.

It should fit some more cases and it fits the current amazon basic cables better than yours (as they are slimmer than the original apple cable which yours is designed for). Furthermore I included some notches to add some weight to the dock to make it heavier.
Greetings

title: Belt clip for Philips Avent baby monitor (babyphone) SCD 560

description.text:
In principle, a baby monitor is a nice thing. Too bad that Philips decided to remove the belt clip for the current version of their DECT babyphones. So if the baby is sleeping and you want to get some stuff done, you still only have one hand free because you have to carry the thing around and it doesn't fit into your pocket. So it is pretty much the same situation as if the baby wasn't sleeping at all (but I have to admit that the baby monitor is much lighter than your average baby).

The solution for this problem is a 3D-printable belt clip. It snaps on the SCD560 phone but could fit other models as well. It prints nicely with supports. I recommend using ~50% infill to make sure that the upper part is stiff enough. Have fun!

UPDATE
I added a new version (V5): Improved stability and should be possible to print without supports! Not tested on the printer yet.

Version (V3): Improved stability of clip + optimized geometry + more rounded corners

description.text:
Thanks to toofuu & aaalberto, I printed their designs and put it to work! After a couple rides, I wanted to make/add a few tweaks to suit my needs.

  1. Make the tension adjuster slightly larger
  2. Added a thumb lever to assist in quick disengagement during a ride. My bike has a good amount of torque ~ a "ball-buster" when you downshift or release the throttle at high speeds. I had to physically roll the throttle forward, causing lots of forward momentum thrust to disengage the lock. So this thumb lever gives you the ability to "unlock" without having to roll the throttle forward.
  3. Added an index finger pin for easier engagement of the lock. It's also removable. Then I went further by adding a 2nd pin location, just in case one location is too close/far for different finger sizes.

As with aaalberto design, recommended hardware to use:
M4 bolt/nut for the tension adjuster and M4 bolt (20mm) and a standard nut. Use stainless of course.

If you decide to try one of these, please take pic and share it?? Thanks!

Printer:

Flashforge Creator (Wooden)

Notes:

Honeycomb infill. I've printed 5 of these things, with 30% -40% infill. All have held up and works great. You can print with heavier infill, if desired. Below 30% might be a little too brittle for this application.

comments.text: if you havent figured it out yet, it goes onto your throttle pointing above your brake. While riding roll your throttle to where you want to keep it and then push this down against your brake lever. as long as you have it tight enough on your throttle, it will hold your throttle in place. to disengage either use the thumb tab or roll your throttle to 0. Very easy to use once you use it a couple times.

description.text:
I recently noticed I was experiencing difficultly reading highway and street signs while riding my motorcycle or driving a car. A visit to the eye doctor determined the symptoms I was experiencing were due to the onset of cataracts (my distance vision was deteriorating, but my close up vision was improving).

For riding and driving, I obtained prescription sunglasses that worked well outdoors, but not so good indoors. So I decided to obtain prescription glasses for indoor use in order to watch movies or television. Unfortunately, after a few weeks of carrying them in my pocket, they broke.

So, I designed and printed this thing to hold my new glasses along with the included soft bag that doubles as a lens cleaner, safely in my pocket. Problem solved (well the broken glasses, not the cataracts).

This is to fix a problem with the Cisco 7900 phones not adjusting the height. Over time an internal plastic part starts to fail and snaps off as you can see from the pictures.

Instructions:

  1. remove back of phone (4 screws are holding it on and a set up clips at the top)
  2. remove the center locking peace
  3. remove the broken plastic part
  4. put the wedge in place at the top
  5. put the locking peace back in
  6. re-attach the back of the phone

title: Tobacco Pusher - Cigarette Machine Addon (Stopfhilfe - Zigarettenmaschine)

description.text:
This thing is an addon for a cigarettemaker. With this thing you can push the tobacco into the slot of the machine. It i a little bit shorter, so you can slide it with the edge a litte bit (like on the pictures).

I know this thing in original only from a cigarettemaker, which makes three cigarettes at one time. This tool is not really usable in my opinion. I'm faster and better with a single-slot maker. But this "push-helper" is a really good help! With this thing i can make a hole package of cigarettes (21 pc.) in ca. 10 minutes. - It's like: Two times of TV Spots and I got my material for the next day. ;)

A time ago i tried to buy this thing, but I couldn't found it anywhere. You got it only with the hole machine. But ... why should I bye two of theese guys (living room & office), when I only need this "tool"? And had I found it ... I'm shure: 1€ for this tool, 2€ for shipping and 3 days delivery. No, thanks.

By the way: It works fine!

Dieses Teil ist ein Addon für einen Zigaretten-Stopfer. Damit kann man den Tabak in den Schlitz der Maschine pressen. Es ist etwas kürzer als der Spalt, sodass man den Tabak noch ein wenig verteilen kann.

Ich kenne dieses Teil ursprünglich von einem "Dreier-Stopfer", der drei Zigaretten auf einmal fertigt. Das klingt praktisch, aber zwei Zigaretten davon sind meistens Mist. Ich komme mit einem einfachen 5€ Stopfgerät von der Kasse wesentlich besser klar. Zusammen mit diesem Stopfer schaffe ich eine Schachtel (ca. 21 Stk.) in etwa 10 Minuten. - Die Portion für den nächsten Tag ist also in zwei Werbepausen gestopft. ;)

Ich habe vor einiger Zeit versucht, dieses Teil einzeln zu kaufen, konnte es aber nirgendwo finden. Ich fand es nur in Kombination mit dem Dreier-Stopfer. Warum sollte ich mir aber zwei davon kaufen (Wohnzimmer & Büro), wenn ich einfach nur zwei von den "Spachteln" brauche? Und ich bin mir sicher: Hätte ich es gefunden, hätte es vielleicht 1€ gekostet. Dazu aber 2€ Versandkosten und drei Tage Versandlaufzeit. Nö.

Es funktioniert gut!

description.text: This is a clamp that attaches directly to the underside of the Mendel deposition bed when used with http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1708 feet. Like the feet, it used No. 4 1/2" countersunk woodscrews or equivalent. The belt is clamped in place by 2 M4 nuts, M4 washers and M4x16mm machine screws. It's kinda neat in that it uses the mess caused when trying to cap a hexagonal hole as a means to entrap a nut.

Get an M4x40 machine screw with washer and put it in the round end of one of the two central holes in the clamp body. Put an M4 nut on the screw and do it up very tightly. This will seat the M4 nut permanently in a wad of loose plastic deposited at the end of each hexagonal hole. Remove the screw and the nut should remain in place. Repeat with other central hole. Put washers on each of two M4x16mm screws and put them in the holes for the end portion of the clamp. Bring the two together to clamp the belt and tighten M4 screws.

title: Scripting and Documenting OpenSCAD designs using openscad-amu and Doxygen
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Using Doxygen with and Scripting OpenSCAD designs.

This thing has been significantly improved. Please see the design flow and template that was developed based on the exploration done here .

Language-based mechanical design, such as that used by OpenSCAD, offers
the potential for increased design efficiencies through the use of
reusable parameterized design libraries. As with software design,
Language-based mechanical design efficiency directly correlates
with well documented robust libraries and good automated design flows.

For some time I have been looking for a good way to both automate (ie: script)
OpenSCAD design flows and document library components. For documentation,
it seems natural to leverage a tool like Doxygen to couple the documentation
with design at the source level where it has the best chance to remain coherent.
Although OpenSCAD is currently the most capable open source CAD tool for
language-based mechanical design, it presently lacks a scripting interface that would
make it more conducive to automated design flows.

This examples present a way to both document OpenSCAD designs and script the
invocation of OpenSCAD for target component compilation.

Pre-build documentation and targets can be found in the file autodoc_pb.zip
and a pre-built PDF reference manual can be found in the file refman_pb.pdf.

To rebuild the documentation yourself from the source file, install the
prerequisite software and then type make. Afterwards view the html-based
documentation by opening the file: autodoc/html/index.html
and the latex generated pdf-version by opening the file:
autodoc/latex/refman.pdf

Meh

Whatever

Notes:

I'd use a dark filament. Translucent and white seemed to allow enough IR through to cause me grief, but I could probably adjust that in code...

--
UPDATE AT BOTTOM OF SUMMARY

I don't play Pokemon Go myself, but I work in IT for a video game company... so almost everyone around me does. I started this design as a first attempt at 3D modeling and it's gone through 5 revisions so far. I was trying to solve the "use it one handed" problem but keep it as universal as possible, and this is my best solution so far.

The idea is the bracket at the bottom will go over the bottle bezzle of your phone. It's designed with an indent to allow for two things:

  1. The part shouldn't hit the buttons on the phone
  2. Allow for a substance like sticky tack to be put inside the model.

The idea is the sticky tack should hold the phone to the screen so you can play one handed, but also be safe to remove and reuse later. The model is sized to fit a phone like the iPhone 4, but the insets should be wide enough so it doesn't hit home/back/menu buttons on Android phones.

The functional part (the aimer) has beveled edges so it's a lot more comfortable to use, and the hole at the base is beveled as well so you should be able to hit your home button.

--
UPDATE: 08/11/2016

  1. Added a Mk5-T model to the pack. Some people with certain models of Samsung were complaining that since the lower bezel on their phone is so small it doesn't work with some cases, specifically the big ones like Otterboxes. I thinned up the lower part of the model by ~6mm. Mk5-T should work on other phones as well.
  2. Actually did some more testing with other sticky tacks, specifically LocTite Fun-Tak Mounting Putty (http://smile.amazon.com/dp/B001F57ZPW) and it works really well. Very happy with the results.

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select v2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

15

Notes:

I only print in PLA right now so keep that in mind. Make typical adjustments for ABS or other material.

Bed temp: 55C
that's my standard, printer's in a cold room, run bed at whatever you're used to running it

Infill: 15%
Infill could go higher so it'll be more ridgid. I printed my Mk.3 design at 40% infill and it was noticibly more ridgid and wasn't significantly wasteful on plastic or print time. I wouldn't do 0% as it's small/thin enough I'd worry about the shell's ridgidity.

Raft/Brim/Skirt: Skirt
To test it I printed with only a skirt, and it prints great as long as you can handle the adhesion. The prongs of the throw area are purposefully a bit wider than necessary to allow for enough adhesion. I've printed 3 batches of 4 heavy, light and no hair spray and had no problem with any.

Supports: None
Hashtag team no support

Print bed layout: model should be ready
If your slicer doesn't load the model correctly, it should be printed with the inset (part that goes against phone screen) facing up. The bevels are angled so the overhang is plenty safe to print as is without supports.

Light sanding may be required

Depending on your printer, light sanding my be required. As the part is honestly quite simple, in terms of the shapes used, the only problem I've had is due to some Z-Axis wobble and/or over extrusion creating pimples that just need to be sanded off.

Designed in TinkerCAD

Link: https://tinkercad.com/things/dkZljZqu5Ex

This is Mark 5 of the part. I used a bunch of people in my office as beta testers. The beveling is from a suggestion, and a lot of attempts were made to hold the part to a phone so it can be used one handed but none of it was universal enough for my liking.

description.text:
Update: See http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1722394 for a version that'll go on a co-ordinating 3D Printed wall plate.

I've got a pile of devices that need charging, and a couple of USB power supplies, and not enough outlets to charge everything at once, so I switched to using an Anker model 71AN7105 5-port 40W, 8A USB Desktop Charger ($24-ish on Amazon), but there were still too many cables and loose bits floating around my desk.

This holds the charger next to a single (duplex) outlet using a standard dual-gang Decora wallplate. It snaps into the empty hole and is held in place with a 3mm insert and a 3x8mm screw, though you could use just about anything to hold it in place.

Note that I used the Leviton R52-PJ262 "Medium/Midway" wall plate, as it's a little larger than the standard one, and we need the extra room for the size of the power supply.

Since the Anker power supply is not centered on the wallplate, there are two versions, with the charger to the Left or Right of the single outlet.

Printer:

Zortrax M200

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.19mm

Infill:

"Low" (minimum)

Notes:

This is about a 6.5 hour print, takes 24.5M (58gm) of filament, and produces a finished part that weighs 51gm.

I used Zortrax "Ultrax" filament, and since I had a lot of it I used "light yellow", which is kinda ivory, though it doesn't match the Almond/Tan outlet and wallplate very well, so unless you have a good match you probably want to use a contrasting color instead.

Press a 3mm insert into the hole.

I use EZ Lok 240-M3-BR which is Global Industrial B435488, which cost more in shipping than they did in parts. Send me a SASE and I'll give you one if they are hard to find in your area.

Sketchup

With judicious use of a caliper, several iterations, and finishing with the Fredo6 RoundCorner tool

title: Engineering Truss Pieces for Education of Statics
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The first section of this project (S1) is to be used in an educational environment to demonstrate the structural rigidity of various shapes, by using a pivot joint on the connections. S1 consists of the single part "Truss_Arm_S1"

The second section of this project (S2) is to be used to assemble various trusses and frames to demonstrate how the shapes work together to build structures, like bridges and buildings. The parts are designed to be connected by pins to demonstrate that fixed joints aren't necessary to build a rigid structure. S2 consists of the rest of the parts not included in S1. This section contains wide possibilities for customization, and I have tried to accommodate for that with the various pin sizes. The arm lengths are more difficult to predict, however, and I am more than happy to add more arms of any requested lengths.

S1 consists of a single beam that has a male and female end that easily snaps together to build shapes.
S2 consists of a number of different lengths of beams as well as pins that connect through the ends of the beams to form connections.

Printer:

Monoprice Select Mini

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Rafts may not be needed depending on your printer. Mine does not immediately begin extruding when it begins printing, so I must use rafts to guarantee that all of the print is properly printed.
There was mild stringing across the holes in the arms, so I quickly ran a round file through the holes to smooth out these imperfections.
These parts were designed in Solidworks 2015 using simple extrusions and cuts, and finally some of the edges were polished using the fillet tool

description.header: Project: Engineering Truss Pieces for the Education of Statics
description.text:
Project Name

Engineering Truss Pieces for the Education of Statics

Overview and Background

This project can be done individually or in groups

This project is designed to display the importance of geometry in designing support structures. The purpose of Section 1 is to show how different geometrical shapes with equal length sides react under outside forces simply by letting the individual push upon various points in the shape.

Section 2 was designed to allow students to assemble various truss structures and be able to feel for themselves the rigidity that different designs can have. Students can build and rebuild their trusses, and once they are satisfied they can give them to the teacher for evaluation or can discuss their designs with the class.

Objectives

This project can be adapted to teach a wide array of concepts. It can be used to demonstrate basic concepts of structural stability, more in depth in promoting students' creativity, or even used in developing problem solving skills using math.

From a basic standpoint, this project can be used to demonstrate and explain the importance of geometry in modern structural engineering. With more pieces, kits can be given to students with various goals, creating a strong but minimal design, or more visually appealing while maintaining strength.

For more advanced education, this project can be used alongside force vectors to teach students how to calculate forces distributed in a truss system from one or more loads combined with two or more supporting points.

Audiences

This project can be adapted for use in almost any grade level, and can even be used in early college courses for additional aid in understanding concepts.

Subjects

Engineering
Math
Physics
Statics

Skills Learned

The key skill this project hopes to develop in students is their ability to determine the effectiveness of a structure by analyzing its design.

Depending on the depth of the lesson, other skills that could be developed is students' ability to apply math to the everyday world, students' ability to design practical objects, or students' ability to discuss and explain the reasoning behind design choices they made or predict reasons that others made their design choices.

Lesson/Activity

To start this activity, use at least four of the "Truss_Arm_S1" parts to demonstrate to students the strength of a triangle over other geometric shapes (I.E. square, pentagon, hexagon). Explain that this is because the ends of each arm are fixed to the others, but these connections do not offer any rotational resistance. The third arm in a triangle fixes the distance that the endpoints of the first two connected legs must be, however that changes as the number of sides increases. When showing a quadrilateral to students, feel free to point out that the shape will always be a rhombus, no matter how much the angles are changed.

The second phase of this activity is to demonstrate how a series of triangles can be used to build functional, rigid structures. This stage can be handled in several ways:
1: The instructor can have several models pre-made for demonstration and discussion.
2: The instructor can have kits of parts put together for students to work with and attempt to build their own trusses. These kits can be assembled to force students into building a specific design or can be assembled to allow students to build whichever design they think of.
3: Students can be tasked with drawing their design on paper, and the instructor can select one or a few to assemble, or can have the class vote on the best design to be assembled.

These are not the only way that the second phase parts can be used however. These are merely suggestions depending on how much time the instructor is willing to spend printing parts.

Duration

This activity can be very short or very long depending on how in depth the instructor would like to go.

Preparation

This activity can be performed with minimal to no knowledge of concepts, but for more in-depth education, students should have a basis of knowledge in geometry and vectors. For deep instruction, students should know how to apply math operations to vectors, knowledge of 2D space, and positive and negative operators.

Rubric & Assessment

If students are given kits to build trusses, they can be graded on several factors based on the goal of the project:
-Structural integrity
-Length of truss
-Simplicity of design
-anything else the instructor sees fit

If students are tasked with drawing up designs to be built, they can be graded on similar factors.

The lengths of the arms are measured from the center of the pinholes. They are in actuality 10mm longer than the indicated length.

The length of pins include overhang to allow the fitting of a cap to hold sections together. This extra length could allow an additional arm to be added to the pin, however the cap may no longer fit on the pin.

The pin spacer and pin cap are not the same part. The pin cap is 2mm in depth and has a tighter tolerance to allow it to hold on to the end of the pins. the pin spacer is 3mm in depth to keep it the same depth as an arm, and thus make up for arms whose faces may not line up. Spacers can been seen in use in the image of the Solidworks assembly consisting of only yellow arms. The pin spacer also has a wider tolerance in the hole, similar to the hole tolerance in the arms, to allow it to easily slide onto the pins like an arm would. This also means they have the ability to spin on the pins.

author: amishboy

title: Printrbot Simple V2 40mm slide out Extruder Fan - Anti filament Jamming

description.text:
I tried printing the hinged version, but sadly, my printer wasn't up for the task. Probably the settings, and there was a mesh error with repetier-host V0.90C. Tried the older slicer version, but gave up after the fifth try. Attached files worked for me. Easy to remove the fan, with the slide out. I used 3MM hex head bolts to hold my fan in. You may have to ream the holes out slightly.   
I had tried a cool fan on the back of the stepper motor, and that kept the stepper nice and cool, but I would still have occasional jams. By mounting the fan this way, stepper gets warm, but not overly hot. After being able to print another complex print, and failing three times(twisted filament), this new fan mounting arrangement solved my problem.   
possible improvements?: I've contemplated putting a port out the bottom, for print cooling at the same time. The thought is, would I be able to eliminate the need for a seperate fan to help with cooling bridging. I would also consider adding a top screw to hold it more securely. That would require drilling a hole into the laser cut wood.
No bridging. I don't think I even had brim turned on. Worked out great.

remixed_from.author: Islemunda
remixed_from.title: Micro Quadcopter Drone Frame V2 (Made for Hubsan X4 electronics)

title: 3D Printed Drone Frame Lesson/Lab with the Hubsan X4

description.text:
Project #8 - Recreating the Hubsan X4 Micro Drone: 3D Printed Drone Frame Lesson/Lab

This project requires a lot of different components, and with the right parts, makes for an incredible learning experience for students in any introduction to robotics/technology/engineering class. Utilizing a custom frame, such as the one in this project from user Islemunda, students can reassemble a new drone from using a 3D printed frame with the electronic components of the Hubsan X4 drone.

Where 3D printing comes in handy with this project is the ability for different student groups to design their projects around different ideas of how to improve the flight capability of their drone, such as increasing/decreasing the thickness of the printed parts or adding additional structural features. If executed correctly, students will walk away from this lesson learning about the basics of electronics, drones, and flight.

**This project requires the purchase of a Hubsan X4 for each group of students. It may also require the purchase of replacement parts in the case of accidents or hardware failure.

Link to purchase Hubsan X4: https://www.amazon.com/Hubsan-H107L-Channel-2-4GHz-Quadcopter/dp/B00IZC6C8E

Link to purchase Crash Parts Kit: https://www.amazon.com/AVAWO-Hubsan-H107L-Quadcopter-Black/dp/B00RRIMMKO/ref=pd_sim_21_1?ie=UTF8&dpID=517lI5-6GiL&dpSrc=sims&preST=_AC_UL160_SR160%2C160_&psc=1&refRID=T97GTBESAA0NSCQZBG8M

The sample 3D STL file included in this project is borrowed from user: Islemunda

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:936847

Printer:

Flashforge 3D Creator Pro

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.27

Infill:

10%-100%

Notes:

For making the drone frame, a higher infill % is desired to prevent damages due to inexperienced pilots :).

It should be left up to the students, however, to experiment and brainstorm on different infill % that may affect their drone's performance.
**Original Photo is from user: Islemunda who created the original drone frame files** The frame on the left is the 3D printed frame and the frame on the right is a Hubsan X4 frame

There are many different steps that will be required to complete this project.

Below are pictures of a dismantling of the Hubsan X4 for the electronic components needed to reassemble the components onto a new 3D printed frame.

Also, a helpful link for assembling the Hubsan X4 and also a list of its components can be found here: http://www.instructables.com/id/SIMPLE-GUIDE-TO-MAKE-a-QUADCOPTER/

Hubsan X4 Opening it up Taking a part the camera module Desoldering the motors Motors Electronic components all removed from the old frame Snapshot of all the parts and pieces from the disassembly of the Hubsan X4

Project #8 - Recreating the Hubsan X4 Micro Drone: 3D Printed Drone Frame Lesson/Lab Students in an engineering/robotics/computer science classroom will work on a custom drone project that involves taking apart the Hubsan X4 microdrone and utilizing the electronic components from it to secure into a 3D printed custom drone frame to fly. The advances in 3D printing and in the filaments that are available for use have allowed makers to make improvements and adjustments to different cases for many devices. In the case of a classroom, there are many applications of engaging in such a project as students will be given a creative opportunity to recreate, and even improve, the function of a pre-existing device - in this case, a microdrone. Objectives
-Students will disassemble a microdrone (Hubsan X4) into its electrical components.
-Students will design/modify a custom drone frame for the creation of a new microdrone through 3D printing.
-Students will reassemble a custom drone using the electrical components from the Hubsan X4 and their 3D printed custom drone frame.

Duration of classes:
This project will require at least 5 separate classes to complete all the steps.
1st class - debrief activity and show appropriate videos on assembly process of Hubsan X4
2nd class - disassembly process of the Hubsan X4 for each group
3rd class - 3D designing and modifying of drone frame + 3D printing them
4th class - assembling new drone with the electrical components from the 2nd class and the printed frame from the 3rd class
5th class - calibrating and testing new drone for flight (see video below for how to calibrate the drone) Lesson plan
Step 1: Show videos of assembly process of the Hubsan X4 to students
Step 2: Brief students on the project and requirements.
Step 3: Have students break into groups of 4
Step 4: Distribute microdrones to each group and initiate the disassembly process
Step 5: Supervise students on disassembly process and ensure safety when using tools (especially the soldering iron)
Step 6: Ensure students label and properly store all of their group's electrical components as they finish with the disassembly process
Step 7: Allow students to create/modify a new drone frame for their microdrone (can utilize the provided STL files)
Step 8: Finalize drone frame designs and 3D print all of them
Step 9: Have students reassemble the drone utilizing the electrical components from the Hubsan X4 and additional support items (adhesives, solder, double-sided tape, etc.)
Step 10: Teacher now should check each group's drone to make sure things are put together safely and accurately (check for broken wires, missing parts, etc.)
Step 11: Calibrate the drone for the appropriate controller (See video below)
Step 12: Test each drone for flight!
Step 13: Debrief activity with students and brainstorm for next steps in possibly upgrading their project to do other things (ie: better camera, propellers, etc.)

Tools Required: 1.Soldering Iron
2.Wire Cutter
3.Wire Stripper
4.Screw Driver Electrical Parts/Drone Parts Required (from the Hubsan X4 drone): Flight Controller Module Rx
Body Shell
Motors
4.Propellers
5.Rubber Feet
6.Blue LEDs
7.Red LEDs
8.Screw Sets
Protection Cover
Battery
Charger
Transmitter
Wrench

-Requirements:
Adequate workshop/class space
3D printers to make the custom drone frames
Safety goggles for students using the soldering iron
Safety gloves
*Computers/laptops with 3D modeling software to make the custom frames
None. - Teacher should assess students based on the overall design and function of each group's drone.

remixed_from.author: nophead
remixed_from.title: Yet Another Prusa Mendel Z Coupling

description.text:
Leveraging existing parts from the Eventorbot to add rigidity to the Y-axis.
The original Eventorbot table tends to swing due to being constrained on only one end. This design provides an anchor to the other end of the table. This was designed for version 1.2, but I expect a different crossbar could make it fit other models as well.

This is designed to be a non-invasive addition (i.e. no additional holes are necessary).  
If desired, the large "wraparound" bracket can be omitted, and two holes can be drilled to place the "little" bracket at the bottom as well.  This will prevent the use of an additional motor, but allow for added airflow into the bottom chamber.  
To connect the crossbar, it is advised to place a 10-32 nut on the existing bed before placing it.  Then add an additional lock nut to hold the crossbar in place.  This serves to space it and to allow you to tighten the crossbar but maintain proper tension on the Y-bearings.  
All screws and nuts are 6-32, except the lead screw, which is 5/16"-18.

comments.text: Its Amazing!  It stops the wobbling, shaking, and some of the noise.  I ran it WITHOUT the threadedrod/motor, and it does a wonderful job.  And now my test cubes have smooth sides instead of rippled sides!

description.text:
greetings, friend ! i made this for my halloween costume last year, a steampunk cybernetic sea captain. I designed it on the CAD website TinkerCAD and printed the final pieces in a total print time around 6 hours (though there were several iterations). i burned myself out on 3d printing and modeling for a few months after making this thing, but i love it and it was totally worth it. it fits okay. you gotta get a bearess to help you adjust the straps, and you'd probably want to use the circle insert to block your vision from the lens, less you gonna have a bad time.

  • it's got a magnifying glass lens in it. the lens is from Michael's, and the magnifying glass' handle unscrewed from the lens fixture very easily.

  • in the photos it's printed black and painted with gold Testor's brand model paint.

  • it's in 4 parts: the main headpiece, the side laser mount, and a small D-bracket and O bracket to secure the strap. the strap is a simple elastic strap from Michael's.

  • The tube thing on the side is a "laser" enclosure which, with a little work, should be able to fit an LED + resistor + AAA battery + some wires.

  • There's a hole on part of the monacle and on the laser enclosure -- you can run some decorative (or functional ?!?!) wires between them.

  • it says "RUN-CMD" on the side of the laser enclosure in a pac-man style font
    • if anyone ever makes one of these i'd absolutely flip out for an action shot

raft? fill layer shells speed temp raft + full support 10 0.27 1 80 150 HBP 115c raft + full support 5 0.2 1 80 150 HBP 118c the laser you glue it to the side of the monacle, i glew it straight on but you can tilt it if you want. get an elastic fabric strap and run it through the strap holes, and like double it over through the D-clip, and then secure the excess strappage in the rectangular binder. pull it wicked tight kid. it's sized for my head

description.text:
Save money by using bags of your own choice with this easy adapter ring and clip.

Fold the top of the bag over the base and clip the ring over with the release tab facing up. place into the Diaper Genie like a normal refill.

I know the old refill rings can be used with a bag and elastic band but I thought this would be easier to use and more reliable.

I think its best to use a big garbage bag so it goes all the way to the bottom. Then there will be room to tie a knot at the top and let it drop through when full. Costco has some nice thick ones.

This is a plaque for http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:154990 I printed both in ABS and used Acetone to glue them together and get a nice finish. I think this size was for the hands while printed at 140% scale. There are three ingresses on the rear so that it can be hooked onto a nail or screw on a wall, I only needed the middle one for mine but included all three just in case there was an in-balance of weight once I had glued the hands on. No Support required

Make sure your build plate is very level.  
If printing in ABS, allow to cool to room temperature before removing or else it will warp.

author: dutchmogul

description.text:
There are times where I did not have a need to put my GoPro on a mount, instead I just wanted to put a string/rope through the holes of the GoPro case. But once the string was on there, it took longer to untie it than it would to just take it off of a mount. So I figured, why not make a mount that had a hole on it where I can put a string through it and leave it on there, and then can easily take off the mount to then attach it to another mount.

I used a 550 Paracord since it is strong, small, and not too expensive. So I made the hole a tad bigger than the paracord (0.20" to be exact) to give you an idea of the size of string/rope that you can use.

author: femoral

description.text:
Crash Probe with optical switch

Using the same process of the Crash Probe http://reprap.org/wiki/CrashProbe but using an optical switch.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hqBF5s-aBCQ

Print Settings:
0.2 height
2 perimeters
2 bottom/top
10% infill
No suport

Required parts:
1 Optical switch OPB829 (PHCT203 or similar)
2 Screws 3x8 (Self-tapping)
2 Neodymium cube de 3x3x3mm N35
1 Paper clip (1mm diameter)
1 Spring 20mm x 8 to 10mm ID (internal diameter) and soft tension

Assembly Instruction

Glue the neodymium cube (Sphere or ball would also work) in the housing of the horizontal rod (StemH.stl), and another at the upper end of the vertical rod (StemV.stl).
 
At the lower end of the vertical rod, use a piece of 20mm paper clip so that the piece does not deform with the heat of the bed. +/- 10mm are out.

The Wall.stl & Strap.stl pieces were created for the model of my printer http://forums.reprap.org/read.php?397,297740 then you may have to redo them to yours.

And Gcode Start in your slicer must have:

G1 Z15 F500; security high
G28 X0 Y0; home X Y axis
G1 X215 F6000; probe down (For my printer! You must find the right distance for your printer)
G28 Z0; home all axis
G29; bal

!!!Caution!!!
Do not use the G28 or G29 of the LCD menu or from computer host because accidents can happen in the probe or in the printer frame
To use them, you need to modify data in ultralcd.cpp file with values to lower the probe before the home.
You can use the same Start Gcode put up to modify the ultralcd.cpp file.
Some lines Start Gcode can be configured directly in firmware.
We managed to make it all work here, this is something that will be easy for you.

Optical switch circuit.
http://reprap.org/wiki/OptoEndstop_2.1

BAL tutorial
http://forums.reprap.org/read.php?151,246132

author: wilson5710

title: Graphs, The Traveling Salesman Problem, and P vs NP

description.text: This activity is for a computer science class or a discrete math class when students first learn about graphs and efficiency of algorithms. This could also be used as an enrichment activity for high school students since it is self-contained with all definitions given and there isn’t any specific background knowledge needed.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

standard

Infill:

10%

I used 123D Design to create a graph using circles and polyline for lines. I used the measure tool to get all the lengths. If you want students to be able to print their graphs you will need to use an object instead of just a line to be able to extrude the graph. I used polyline to create rectangles. My graph only took 6 minutes to print, but it is fragile. You could scale it up. I chose not to so that it would print with the same dimensions I measured for the project.

Students get an introduction to graphs using the Kevin Bacon Game. Then they will learn some vocabulary terms, including Hamiltonian circuit. Students use 123D Design to create graphs. This will lead to an introduction to The Traveling Salesman Problem. From there they will look at the efficiency of algorithms and P vs NP. Objectives:
Students will learn the definitions and get practice for the following terms: Graphs, Hamiltonian circuit, The Traveling Salesman Problem, and algorithm efficiency. Skills Learned (Standards):
Students learn what a graph is, how to recognize and create a Hamiltonian circuit, how to solve The Traveling Salesman Problem, and get an introduction to algorithm efficiency.

Further detail is provided in the student and teacher worksheets.
To introduce what graphs are go to https://oracleofbacon.org. Ask students to give you actor names to get a few connections and start drawing a graph on the board. Make the actors vertices and movies they were in together edges. Then explain that graphs are made up of edges (lines) and vertices (dots).
Show a clip from Good Will Hunting that has an example of a graph: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Bylkoiyz7Ww
Define a walk, a circuit, and a Hamiltonian circuit.
In groups students create a graph with a Hamiltonian circuit using 123D Design and measure the length of each edge. Then they trade with another group to locate the circuit.
Introduce the Traveling Salesman Problem and students us their graph to go through an example.
Students think about how many possibilities they have to check for a route with n cities.
Show a factorial, exponential, and polynomial graphed on the same set of axes to show that the polynomial function grows much slower than the other two.
Go through an example that is solved in polynomial time.
Explain P vs NP
Show clips from Elementary that go into P vs NP in further detail.
1-2 days
No specific background knowledge is needed.

Here is a sample rubric to use with the worksheet: Question (points)
1 (2)
2 (6)
3 (4)
4 (2)
5 (8)
6 (1)
7 (2) Total (25)
All the definitions and background you need is included in this activity.

title: Wanhao I3 V2.1 Cobra Fan adapter

description.text:
Dec 12, 16 - Update. Saw a few comments about the adapter do not fit. I enlarged the opening and give it some extra space. Now even printing at 0.2 mm resolution, there is enough room. Also, I made an new version for the Cobra Fan with the horizontal fan mount. The -23 is for the vertical fan and -39 version is for the horizontal fan.

Sep 11, 16 - Updated base on comment and added a slot. It should fit the fat and non-fat version of the cobra fan. Use version 9. Previous version is there as reference.

This is a mounting adapter for the Cobra Fan to be use on the Wanhao Duplicator I3 V2.1 or previous versions of I3 using the Wanhao 2.1 upgrade kit. The X-axis aluminum bearing blocks are replaced with wider plastic ones. An spacing adapter is needed to mount the Cobra Fan and keep it in the same position as before. Two (at least one) M4 24 mm bolt is needed. No need to thread the bearing block as the plastic blocks already has the M4 nuts

Note, do not use M4 bolt longer then 24mm as it will lift the plastic bearing bracket off the X-axis metal mounting bracket.

Wanhao Duplicator I3

title: Shelf Support for Munchkin High Capacity Drying Rack

description.text:
As parents of a five-month old, we've been washing and drying a lot of bottles. I bought a Munchkin High Capacity Drying Rack for holding all of the baby's bottles and other assorted feeding gear.

Unfortunately, what I've found is as the upper shelf bears more weight, it puts enough pressure on the center column's tabs and the shelf eventually collapses down onto the lower shelf.

Over time, this got pretty annoying. Eventually, I grabbed my calipers and designed an object to manage the height that the shelf sits on top of instead of using the flimsy little shelves.

author: briancmoses

description.text:
UPDATE:
Fixed a bug on the hour gear. Download the fixed STL and if you are interested in it, all three OpenSCAD files as well.
UPDATE This is a cleaned up version of the printed clock we were able to make during Clockathon #2 last weekend. Thank you Makerbot and Bre for setting that up and hosting it, and thank you Ben for all the help, the awesome test print all set up, and the brilliant idea to back off one gear for the power drum. It was ticking, powered by a weight that would only drop about 9" per twelve hour period, and included printed concentric shafts to support minute and hour hands on the face of the clock. Here's some video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AH4Tg2tIgfg
I had to inflict grievous harm to the code base at the time and have cleaned everything up since. See details below.

From the makerbot clockmaker google group: So I cleaned up the code from clockathon 2, and implemented the changes discussed.
  • Changed the gearing to add another factor of two to account for the fifteen tooth escapement wheel. Still six gears total.
  • Deprecated the old drumgear routine that could only be used on the front of the clock and replaced it with the core pinion wheel routine, which can now include a non ratcheting drum on any gear, and can now produce a gear with no pinion if you set the number of teeth on the pinion to zero.
  • Implemented some logic to use one shaft radius (bearingRadius) if the gear has no concentric shaft, and another (pinRadius) if it does. This way, the design automatically assumes you place bearings on all the gears that do not include a concentric shaft.
  • Changed the parameters to include concentric shafts and hands for the hour gear and the minute gear.
    • With these changes, it is now possible to generate the same clock we had at the end of clockathon 2, without touching the code or the parameters incessantly. What it currently does NOT do is include a ratcheting drum solution for any other gear than the front one, or a way to turn the fixed drum on for only one gear (right now, you just turn it on while rendering the gear(s) you want with drums, and turn it off for the rest). The standard config right now is bearings on all gears except hours and minutes, concentric printed shafts resting directly on M5 threaded rod (had to guess at a good radius value there) for the two exceptions, and a 5mm wide non-ratcheting drum on the gear between hours and minutes. Today's respite from business travel does not extend to tomorrow, unfortunately, so I will post this code base later today, with some STLs and some screen grabs... And you guys can give it a spin. Ha! See what I did there? ;-)

comments.text: If there's a way to send you a private note I haven't figured it out yet.  (I only came to thingiverse the first time yesterday.)

comments.text: I cannot tell you how long I have been looking for a mechanical clock to 3D print ot laser cut that actually works that my students and I can use to learn how a clock works...how difficult is this to assemble once parts are printed?

comments.text: Not hard at all, but as we don't have a printed case and the parts aren't numbered or labelled, it still takes a little extra DIY. Mostly we've been mounting everything on a board, with a printed box to hold up the shafts.

comments.text: When we finalize the design, we'll have a complete set with labelled parts and a case to print. Meanwhile, it's still a little beta. ;-)

comments.text: We switched to those bearings when Ben opted for M5 rod, the M3 having a tendency to bend under the weight on the drum. Ben found these bearings and we haven't looked back... Although we are thinking of standardizing to something easier to find.

comments.text: I live not far from a huge manufacturing center, and I asked around at the industrial bearing supply shops. I got pretty much laughed at, but I did take a look at a really nice tapered roller bearing with a 5000mm ID!!! It was a steal at $122,000.
comments.author: syvwlch

comments.text: lol
comments.author: Surveyor

comments.author: Surveyor

comments.text: Hum... There's something wrong with that part. There shouldn't be that cylinder sticking out the bottom and the hole should go all the way thru. Must be something wrong with my code in OpenSCAD.
comments.author: Surveyor

comments.text: Ah ha! I have all the pieces in front of me, and thought 'why doesn't this gear have a through hole??'.
comments.author: syvwlch

comments.text: Yeah, redid the code on that one since the clockathon. It looked right in F5 view but apparently it rendered weird in F6 and I didn't notice when I exported the STL... You can try to drill it out but I will make a new STL this weekend. Been traveling for work and openSCAD doesn't work on my laptop. :-(
comments.author: Surveyor

comments.text: No sweat, glad I could bring it to your attention. There's also a 1mm (or so) protrusion on the bottom that actually renders below the build surface.
comments.author: syvwlch

comments.text: Ok, fixed it. Turns out, when you difference a cylinder from another cylinder with a radius of zero, the result is invisible in F5 view, but renders as the first cylinder in F6 view and in your STL exports... Who knew? :-)
comments.author: Surveyor

comments.text: Silly questions time!
comments.author: Daid

comments.text: No such thing as a silly question. :-)
comments.author: Daid

comments.text: Oh, now I see where you put the string... that's one small guide. When I generate a full clock with the OpenSCAD code, all gears have that guide?
comments.author: syvwlch

comments.text: The guide is always there, and it's length along the shaft is controlled by a parameter called spacer. I would recommend leaving it at one millimeter when rendering all the gears except the one you want to put the weight on, and increasing it to something like five or ten millimeters for that one.
comments.author: Daid

comments.text: Oh, in the STLs posted here, I already did render gear number two with a higher value of the spacer parameter...
comments.author: syvwlch

comments.author: Daid

comments.text: Actually, we're starting to think that, except for the drum holding the weight that powers the clock, radial loads are low enough that bearings aren't strictly necessary... But they do prevent wear, eliminate some slop and eliminated friction as a variable during the testing.

Tipsy Bartender coasters! Stay tipsy my friends! I haven't printed this design yet. Once I print I will update this summary.

Looked around at a bunch of 3d printed shift knobs. Some were simple some were complex. It seemed they lacked mass. The downside of 3dprinting a shift knob is at the end of the day its just a hunk of plastic. My 2002 Mazda Miata has a decent shift knob so as an exercise I measured that up. Here it is! Its a 3 part shift knob that includes a cavity for placing weights. My first thought was to use lead solder and wrap the inside cavity. I have since decided using bird shot would be a quicker solution(look for an update). Shift pattern up top did not print the way I wanted so I will probably be adding additional tops (6spd, 4spd, no spd....). Mine press fit together just fine I would add some glue to make it more permanent. Hole in knob is 10mm non threaded.

Notes:

This is just an experiment, where I am going to make my own speaker using cardboard, 0.4mm enamelled copper wire for the voice coil, and 10mm round neodyne magnets as the moving magnet.

The voice coil in this speaker is fixed in place.

This is very much a work in progress, if it even works at all.

When printing, use supports.

Cheers.

After printing.....

Remove all support material, leaving just the speaker frame as intended.
Cut out a round piece of manilla folder cardboard and glue it to the round frame.

Wind about 50 ~ 100 turns of 0.4mm copper wire onto the bobbin at the top of the printed frame.

Use a stick magnet (or a stack of 10mm neodyne magnets) and stick it to the centre of the cardboard cutout that you made earlier. Make sure that the magnet passes through the voice coil.

Strip the enamel from either end of the voice coil, and tin the ends with solder.

Use an M3 screw and nut on either side of the voice coil to terminate the windings. (You can use solder lugs here for better results).

Feed it with a low level audio signal (from a pocket radio for example) and see if you can hear the reproduced audio.

I will include pictures of mine once I get it done, which will be easier to follow than my written instructions!

This is a remix of the "caja nodemcu 1.0 by toniet"

I modified the files to lower the bottom to avoid holes in the bottom of the box.
I raised the top to increase the size for the USB hole.
I increased the overlapping side from bottom and top for a better locking of the parts when assembled.

Observations:

  1. I printed the bottom in the vertical position because the printer nozzle is 0.4 mm while the layering can be done at 0.1. If you print it horizontally you might not be able to insert the board.

  2. Turn the top upside down for printing because it does not have supports.

Thanks for the original.

20
Servo base for Sparkfun's Servo - Generic (Sub-Micro Size) Dimensions of the servo are on its datasheet:

Can be 3D printed or lasercut (I lasercut it in 3mm stock). Based on the datasheet, I modelled the servo in OpenScad, then designed a suitable base around it. See stand.stl Then sliced every 3mm -> dxf , manually repositioned for economy in stand_layout.dxf lasercutting
=========
Boltholes are provided to hold everything together with M2 bolts. Cut using the dxf.
  • You'll need at least 6 layers of the small holder cross section plus the base pieces. Any less and the servo won't fit.
  • One of the layers should be the u-shaped one (exit point for servo cable).
  • 4 * M2 bolts thread through the base disk and the holder cross-sections. Nut goes at the top.
  • Check that the bolts won't catch on the servo mechanism.
  • If the bolts are too long, either cut them or add a few more layers.
  • The annular ring simply attaches with e.g. pva glue. It raises the unit above the bolt heads.
    • You may want to screw the servo down to the holder. I found it unnecessary -- the fit is snug. 3DPrinting
    ========
    Not attempted, but should be ok. Modifying
    =======
    The scad file should be self-explanatory. You might want to comment out the $fa and $fs until your final version. Prefix the servo() line in module all()with * to hide it. Last 2 lines determine whether you produce a 3D model or projections: for the 3d model, use: all(); *projections(3); ... and export the result as STL for dxf slices, use: *all(); projections(3); ... and export the result as DXF.

author: flopi

description.text:
EDIT: Sorry for the mis-oriented part. I can't seem to get it to export right so it will turn out flat. I always seem to have this problem.

A lightweight minimalistic frame for toy micro quads with 7mm motors. Very flexible and very durable! Your mileage may vary when fitting your main board and battery, but I designed this frame around a "HVR mini drone with video camera". It is a common design, so this may work for many different micro quads in a similar fashion. (I quickly removed the video camera part by carefully desoldering its pins from the main board)

I secured the main board, battery, and motors with hot-melt glue. Be careful if you used PLA to print like I did, as it becomes soft at the high glue temperatures.

The file is saved as 0.06" thick. With 0.3mm layer height, you will get a 5-layer frame. That is much stiffer, but also heavier. Whet I found worked well was scaling the Y-axis to make the part around 1/2 as tall to make it a 3-layer print. You can also get fancy like I did for this final frame I am using, and kill the print after it finishes the borders on the 4th layer to get that little bit of extra rigidity.
You will probably have to ream out the motor holes. I did it carefully by hand with a 1/4" drill bit.

author: chev383

print_settings.Notes:: recommended

title: 2-in-1 Cable and Filament Guide for Prusa i3 EG-1

description.text:
I needed a guide that could keep both cable and filament tidy. Current models on Thingiverse were designed for Prusa i3's with a single-panel frame, but ElectronicGeek's EG-1 had a second panel to hold the LCD control panel in-place. Also, none of the existing models were created for double duty.

This design includes an upper fork to hold the cable with sufficient clearance for the filament to be guided down the middle of the printing platform. Additional supports on the sides keep the guide firmly in-place. Once mounted, if the filament has already been fed into the extruder, simply slide the filament into the guide using the open end. Keep the filament in the loop by closing it with the clip.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3 EG-1

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

200 microns or less

Infill:

15%

Notes:

The uploaded models were rotated to ensure maximum adhesion and optimal print material consumption. Tweak as necessary. Supports are definitely recommended for the main structure!
